importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico in Handlova, Slovakia, where Juraj Cintula shot at him from close range.
The date of the final verdict by the Specialized Criminal Court in Banska Bystrica, which convicted Juraj Cintula of terrorism and sentenced him to 21 years in prison.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the assassination attempt occurred and the subsequent legal proceedings unfolded, highlighting political tensions in Slovakia.

keyTakeAways: A Slovak court sentenced Juraj Cintula, 72, to 21 years in prison for attempting to assassinate Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024.
Cintula, who admitted shooting at Fico five times from a distance of over one meter, claimed he wanted to stop Fico’s policies that he believed damaged Slovak freedom and culture.
The court ruled that Cintula’s act constituted terrorism, not just murder or an attack on a public official, citing the specific targeting of the prime minister as a key factor.

The verdict reflects deep societal divisions in Slovakia, particularly between the populist Fico government and the liberal, pro-EU opposition, which accuses Fico of undermining democratic values and media freedom.
Fico, who suffered serious injuries, has returned to public life and has expressed forgiveness toward Cintula, while critics argue his policies have eroded democratic standards.
Cintula, a former mine worker, stone mason, writer, and public activist, has stated that the attack was a 'scream against fear' paralyzing society.
The case has sparked national debate over the use of violence in political conflict and whether attacks on political figures constitute terrorism.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Slovak court sentenced 72-year-old Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison for attempting to assassinate Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024 during a public greeting in Handlova. Cintula, a former mine worker and public activist, shot at Fico five times from close range, claiming he wanted to stop policies he believed damaged Slovak freedom and culture. The Specialized Criminal Court in Banska Bystrica ruled that the attack constituted terrorism due to its targeted nature against a political leader, despite Cintula's claim that he did not intend to kill. The verdict reflects deep societal divisions in Slovakia between Fico’s populist, pro-Moscow policies and the liberal, pro-EU opposition, which accuses Fico of undermining democracy. Fico, who survived with serious injuries, has returned to public duties and expressed forgiveness toward Cintula. The case has sparked a national debate over the legitimacy of political violence and the boundaries of terrorism in political discourse.
title: Slovakia Court Sentences Suspect in Attempted Assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico to 21 Years
